name: Big Five (OCEAN) Workspace
description: Analysis tools for the Big Five personality model
author: OCEAN Personality Dynamics

traits.name: Openness to Experience
traits.description: Reflects the degree of intellectual curiosity, creativity, and preference for novelty and variety.

facets.name: Imagination
facets.description: The tendency to create an internal world of fantasy.

facets.name: Artistic Interests
facets.description: Appreciation for art, music, poetry, and beauty.

facets.name: Emotionality
facets.description: Awareness and exploration of one's own feelings.

facets.name: Adventurousness
facets.description: Eagerness to try new activities and experience different things.

facets.name: Intellect
facets.description: Intellectual curiosity and interest in abstract ideas.

facets.name: Liberalism
facets.description: Openness to re-examining values and traditions.

interpretations.high: People high in openness are intellectually curious, open to emotion, sensitive to beauty and willing to try new things. They tend to be creative and aware of their feelings.
interpretations.moderate: People with moderate openness scores are practical but willing to consider new ways of doing things. They seek a balance between the traditional and the new.
interpretations.low: People low in openness prefer the plain, straightforward, and obvious over the complex, ambiguous, and subtle. They often regard the arts and sciences with suspicion and prefer familiar routines.

traits.name: Conscientiousness
traits.description: Reflects the tendency to be organized, responsible, and hardworking.

facets.name: Self-Efficacy
facets.description: Confidence in one's ability to accomplish things.

facets.name: Orderliness
facets.description: Tendency to be organized and neat.

facets.name: Dutifulness
facets.description: Strong sense of duty and moral obligation.

facets.name: Achievement-Striving
facets.description: Need for personal achievement and high aspirations.

facets.name: Self-Discipline
facets.description: Ability to begin tasks and carry them through to completion.

facets.name: Cautiousness
facets.description: Disposition to think through possibilities before acting.

interpretations.high: People high in conscientiousness are organized, reliable, and methodical. They have strong self-discipline, aim for achievement, and prefer planned rather than spontaneous behavior.
interpretations.moderate: People with moderate conscientiousness balance reliability with flexibility. They are generally organized but can adapt to changing circumstances.
interpretations.low: People low in conscientiousness tend to be more laid-back, spontaneous, and creative. They may be disorganized and sometimes unreliable, but can be more flexible and adaptable.

traits.name: Extraversion
traits.description: Reflects the tendency to seek stimulation in the company of others and to express positive emotions.

facets.name: Friendliness
facets.description: Interest in and friendliness towards others.

facets.name: Gregariousness
facets.description: Preference for the company of others.

facets.name: Assertiveness
facets.description: Tendency to take charge and direct the activities of others.

facets.name: Activity Level
facets.description: Pace of life; level of busyness.

facets.name: Excitement-Seeking
facets.description: Need for environmental stimulation.

facets.name: Positive Emotions
facets.description: Tendency to experience positive emotions.

interpretations.high: People high in extraversion are outgoing, energetic, and draw energy from social interactions. They are talkative and assertive, and thrive in dynamic environments with lots of people.
interpretations.moderate: People with moderate extraversion enjoy social situations but also value their alone time. They can be outgoing when needed but also appreciate quiet reflection.
interpretations.low: People low in extraversion (introverts) are reserved, reflective, and prefer less stimulating environments. They may be perceived as quiet or withdrawn but often have deep focus and concentration.

traits.name: Agreeableness
traits.description: Reflects the tendency to be compassionate and cooperative rather than suspicious and antagonistic towards others.

facets.name: Trust
facets.description: Belief in the sincerity and good intentions of others.

facets.name: Morality
facets.description: Sincerity and straightforwardness; unwillingness to manipulate.

facets.name: Altruism
facets.description: Active concern for the welfare of others.

facets.name: Cooperation
facets.description: Willingness to compromise and accommodate others.

facets.name: Modesty
facets.description: Tendency to be humble and self-effacing.

facets.name: Sympathy
facets.description: Attitude of compassion for others.

interpretations.high: People high in agreeableness are trusting, helpful, and empathetic. They tend to be cooperative, warm, and concerned with the well-being of others.
interpretations.moderate: People with moderate agreeableness balance cooperation with self-interest. They can be warm and considerate but also stand up for themselves when needed.
interpretations.low: People low in agreeableness tend to be more competitive, skeptical, and challenging. They may be perceived as tough-minded, analytical, and less concerned with social harmony.

traits.name: Neuroticism
traits.description: Reflects the tendency to experience negative emotions and psychological distress.

facets.name: Anxiety
facets.description: Tendency to worry and be apprehensive.

facets.name: Anger
facets.description: Tendency to experience anger and related states.

facets.name: Depression
facets.description: Tendency to experience feelings of guilt, sadness, and hopelessness.

facets.name: Self-Consciousness
facets.description: Sensitivity to criticism and social rejection.

facets.name: Immoderation
facets.description: Tendency to act on cravings and urges.

facets.name: Vulnerability
facets.description: Susceptibility to stress and difficulty coping.

interpretations.high: People high in neuroticism tend to experience more negative emotions like anxiety, anger, and depression. They may be more reactive to stress and interpret ordinary situations as threatening.
interpretations.moderate: People with moderate neuroticism experience a normal range of emotions with occasional periods of negative feelings that they generally manage well.
interpretations.low: People low in neuroticism (high in emotional stability) tend to be calm, even-tempered, and less easily upset. They are less reactive to stress and generally more relaxed.

tools.name: Trait Analysis
tools.description: Analyze individual traits and their interactions

tools.name: Facet Breakdown
tools.description: Detailed analysis of the six facets within each trait

tools.name: Career Matching
tools.description: Match personality traits to suitable career paths

key_studies.title: The Five-Factor Model of Personality Across Cultures
key_studies.summary: Examination of the Big Five model across different cultural contexts.

key_studies.title: Personality in Adulthood: A Five-Factor Theory Perspective
key_studies.authors: McCrae, R. R., & Costa, P. T.
key_studies.summary: Comprehensive overview of the Five-Factor Theory and its implications.

meta_analyses.title: Personality Traits and Personal Values: A Meta-Analysis
meta_analyses.authors: Parks-Leduc, L., Feldman, G., & Bardi, A.
meta_analyses.summary: Meta-analysis examining relationships between Big Five traits and personal values.
